sp.p: (entering, R.) Well, I'm sure, Mr. Nibble, to run away and leave me in the middle of a dance—and a pretty dance I've had after you. How mean!

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: (confused) Well, you see, Miss Touchemup—

div.stage: JOE SIMPSON re—appears, L.

sp.speaker: Miss T.
sp.p: And the watch and chain? I've seen nothing of them yet.

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: We'll see about that presently. Come along, uncle.

sp.speaker: Miss T.
sp.p: What, are you off again?

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: Shan't be a minute. Come along, uncle. (drags POYNTER hastily off, L.)

sp.speaker: Miss T.
sp.p: No, no—stop!—come back (calling) Nobby! Mr. Nibble! (runs off after them, L.)

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (sitting at table, as before) It was not her. (stage is clear now) If after all she should not come.

div.stage: Music, piano, and distant shouts of laughter—JANE RUTHERFORD appears at back, L., elegantly dressed; she is pale and agitated and casts scared looks around her as she advances.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I have arrived! A tradesman whom formerly I knew was good enough to lend me these clothes for an hour or so, and I—

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (aside) It is she!

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Oh, this noise and gaiety! how they torture me! I am craving to return to my poor Jessie, to carry her the aid of which I have received a promise. I must plunge amidst the crowd in order that I may find (going R., is met by SYDNEY) Ah, 'tis he (hurrying to him) Oh, Mr. Weston!

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (aside) My rival!

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: (surprised) You know me?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I was awaiting you. Have you not written to me, asking me to come hither?

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: I? Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: What matters; 'tis heaven sends you!

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: Pardon me, but I cannot recall to my mind—

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I am that woman whom, a month ago, you so generously defended.

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: Ah, yes; at the tavern—I recognize you now. You here!—and thus! (pointing to dress)

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Oh, the question is not now of me, but of her.

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: (starting) Of her!

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (aside) Infernal encounter!

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Yes; of Lady Marian.

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: Oh, pronounce not that name, which reminds me of a treachery that almost killed me, and which in noise and so—called pleasure, I am striving to forget.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: You accuse the poor child, when for your sake she has sacrificed everything.

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: How say you?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: That she might preserve to you her love, that she might continue faithful to you, Marian has quitted Lord Chesterton's house.

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: (joyfully) She is still free?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Yes, free; and fled to escape a hateful marriage, and since that time has lain concealed with me, her companion—the confidant of her sorrows—in a miserable dwelling, enduring all the horrors of the lowest and most abject poverty.

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: And I, wretch that I am, have been cursing her! Come, come—conduct me to her.

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (aside, rising) He must not be suffered again to see her!

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (grasping SYDNEY's arm) Yes, yes—let us hasten! (is dragging SYDNEY away to L. U. E., when their passage is barred by SIMPSON, who has hastily advanced—music)

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (frightened) Simpson!

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: Pray excuse me, young gentleman, but you cannot go hence with this lady, for she has promised to depart with me.

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: (greatly surprised) How?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (vehemently) 'Tis false believe him not! 'Tis false, I say that man is your rival!

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: My rival—he! Come, sir, stand aside and let us pass!

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (determinedly) You depart not with her!

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: (losing patience) What insolence—stand aside! (thrusting him away)

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (raising his cane) You dare to—

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: (clutching his arm) Wretch! you shall account to me for this insult.

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: How, and when you please.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (greatly agitated) Oh, for heaven's sake—

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: Now, on the instant!

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: No thank you; I have no desire to find myself within the clutches of the police. (giving SYDNEY a card on which he has written with a pencil) but if, an hour hence, you will meet me there—

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: (without looking at card) I shall be there, doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: I should know you for a coward should you fail to your promise. (aside) I must keep them well in view. Exit, R.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (looking at card in SYDNEY'S hand and starting) Oh, go not to that place! your life would be in danger! (SYDNEY turns up, impatiently, without heeding her) Oh, heaven, he does not listen to me; You know not of what that wretch is capable!

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: (stopping near her) I know that he is my rival—that he has insulted me, and that I will kill him! (giving a portemonnaie to JANE) Here, take this money—go, succour dear Marian, assure her of my love, that I have never loved but her, and this evening, if heaven protects me, I will hasten and rejoin you.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (endeavouring to detain him) But, listen to me—listen—

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: (breaking from her) I cannot! I have my love, and my honour to avenge—farewell, farewell! (hurries off at back, L.)

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Oh, they will kill him! Simpson would be rid of a rival! I understand his infamous purpose, and shall I suffer them brutally to slaughter the man who loves my daughter? No, no—he slain, Jessie too would die! But what can I do? Jessie now awaits my return to her —her anguish and her sufferings are increasing every moment—oh, what can I do—on what can I resolve? (going up)

div.stage: Enter POYNTER, L., dressed in Nobby's clothes, and struts about admiring himself.

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: My nephew didn't look half as well in these clothes as I do!

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (recognizing and running to him) Mr. Poynter!

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: (greatly surprised) Mrs. Rutherford—you here—and dressed out like that?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I have not time now to explain to you anything—but you can render me a great service.

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: What's that?

div.stage: Re—enter JOE SIMPSON—glides behind tuft of flowers, and listens.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Take this purse and, without losing a moment, hasten with it to my lodging, to my daughter, who is suffering, famishing—

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: Mercy on us!

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Her salvation—her life is at stake!

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: (moved) Poor thing! (taking purse) I'll go—I'll go.

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: How shall I contrive to prevent him? (aside)

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Oh, thanks, thanks! (aside) And now to watch over and, if heaven aid me, save Sydney Weston. Exit, L. U. E.

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: If I could find some one dependable instead of going myself, for I don't fancy having put on these clothes for nothing.

div.stage: SNIPPER runs on, followed by WAITERS, PEOPLE, &c., R.

sp.speaker: Snipper.
sp.p: There he is that's the thief!

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: (looking amongst people that surround him) Where? where's the thief? Where is he? I'll soon—

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: (collaring him) You are the thief—you!

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: Miss T.
sp.p: (surprised) No—he isn't a thief—he's a—

sp.speaker: Snip.
sp.p: He can't deny it. (pointing) Those are the clothes he stole from me.

sp.speaker: Miss T.
sp.p: Oh, gracious! (PEOPLE groan at POYNTER)

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: But I assure you—

div.stage: Enter NOBBY, as policeman, L.

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: Hold the villain tight! I know him well! (murmurs of indignation)

sp.speaker: Miss T.
sp.p: (aside) Why that's Nobby.

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: You rascal! would you dare—

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: (imitating him) Can't help it you know, here's proof.

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: And do you dare to—

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (aside) Now I'm off to pretty Marian. (disappears)

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: (struggling) If you don't let me go—

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: I call upon everybody, in the queen's name, to assist me. Take him to the station house. (POYNTER is hustled and pushed about—NoBBY and MISS T. point and jeer at him, and he is carried off as a grand galop is commenced on the platform, amidst noises, shoutings and laughter)

div.head: ACT III.

div.stage:
SCENE. A Vault or Cellar, which is reached by descending some dilapidated steps, C.; a small grated window looking into the street, L. C.; a bundle of straw, R.; a large barrel and two or three stools, L.—Feebly lighted by some candles stuck in an iron chandelier. THIEVES and BEGGARS, male and female, discovered; most of them very ragged; some are lying on the ground, others seated on the floor, playing at cards, and three or four men seated
around the barrel, on which are bottles and glasses; several men and one or two of the women are smoking short pipes.—Music.

sp.l: With gin, and with baccy, and beer,
In this cellar so jolly are we!
No peelers are here!
We're ready for work or a spree,
With gin, and with baccy, and beer!

div.stage: Enter NOBBY NIBBLE, down steps.

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: Holloa, pretty night—birds! my beautiful bats! you set of screech owls, that haven't got a feather to fly with!

sp.speaker: Hooker.
sp.p: Come, I say, Mr. Nobby, what's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: I have promised my young woman a watch and chain and haven't been able to put my hand on 'em. (all laugh) I suppose none of you have tumbled over anything of the sort?

sp.speaker: Hooker.
sp.p: No such luck.

sp.speaker: Snatcher.
sp.p: (listening) I say, what's that noise I hear down there? (pointing)

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: Have you lately tumbled out of the moon, that you don't know?

sp.speaker: Snatcher.
sp.p: I never was in this place afore to—night.

sp.speaker: Hooker.
sp.p: He's a friend of mine; I interdoosed him.

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: Oh! Well, my unenlightened friend, I'll explain all about the noise under your feet. It's the Thames a—rising.

sp.speaker: Snatcher.
sp.p: Does all the Thames pass under this cellar?

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: No, you idiot! But look here. (goes up to wall at back) Just here there's a spring, and when you press it hard a large trap opens, just there. (pointing) And when the tide is up the water flows in under the cellar, and when it goes out again carries everything out into the river along with it. If a fellow finds himself down there—my crickey!—he ought to know how to swim a bit.

sp.speaker: Hooker.
sp.p: And when the tide is out a fellow can hide down there, if any of the gentlemen in blue should be arter him.

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: Here, my friend, just come and stand on the trap a minute, and I'll give you an opportunity of judging for yourself what it's like down there at the present moment.

sp.speaker: Snatcher.
sp.p: (retreating) No, thank you. (all laugh)

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: (coming forward) You wouldn't be drowned, because you are safe to be hanged. It's what all we night—birds come to at last. (all laugh)

sp.l: With night there comes our turn to sing,
The flats they then succumbs;
Pickpockets then are on the wing,
A—picking up their crumbs.
The thief by night to work departs,
For then it is he's right;
With beak stretch'd out, then glides and darts
The bird that flies by night.
B—r—o—o! (imitating the noise of wings)
They go rattle and pat,
Abroad and awake is the bat.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: The nice little bat. F—r—o—o!

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.l: By day in a fright—
He flies boldly by night.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: He goes rattle and pat,
sp.l: Wide awake is the bat.

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.l: Sooner or later, 'tis too true,—
I've often thought it odd—
A peeler says "Here, I want you,"
And walks you off to quod.
They lock you in a nasty cell,
That's the way they bag you;
And soon you don't feel very well—
Crick (imitating being hanged)
For that's the way they scrag you.
Crack! (as before)
Unpleasant ending that—
Off for a long sleep goes the bat.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Yes, that's the way they scrag you.

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.l: That's the way they scrag you,
And that's the way they bag you.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: F—r—o—o! (imitating noise of wings)
Unpleasant ending that—
Off for a long sleep goes the bat.

div.stage: JANE RUTHERFORD—very miserably dressed, disguised with red hair, &c. descends the steps.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (aside) He is not here!

sp.speaker: Hooker.
sp.p: Holloa, missus, who are you?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Who am I?

sp.speaker: Hooker.
sp.p: Here, Nobby; here's your young woman come after the watch and chain. (all laugh)

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: No, thank you; my young woman isn't an old 'un, and she hasn't got golden locks.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (aside, glancing rapidly around) How shall I discover?—

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: Here, I say, who are you? You can't come here without being properly introduced. We're genteel and select, we are.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I'm a friend of Mrs. O'Leary's; she'll be here presently and she'll pay my footing for me.

sp.speaker: Hooker.
sp.p: Oh, if you're a friend of Mother O'Leary's, that's all right enough.

div.stage: Music—JOE SIMPSON appears on top of steps—all go up to meet him. JANE throws herself down behind heap of straw, R. so as to be almost concealed from JOE, &c.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Good evening, Mr. Simpson.

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (advancing) I have an appointment here at nine o'clock with a gentleman a friend of mine will show him the way here. (looking at his watch) Ah, I am not here a minute too soon.

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: (aside, sighing) Ah he's got a watch and chain, he has! (a whistle without)

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: Hush! here comes my man. Ladies and gentlemen, your fashionable style of dress might rather astonish him; so here, (giving money) perhaps you will be good enough to drink my health, and when I want you again, I'll call you.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Good luck to you, Mr. Simpson. (they go off, L.)

div.stage: (Music—NOBBY following last sees SYDNEY WESTON, who appears on top of steps)

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: (aside) Eh? Why, that's the young gentleman as damaged my nose! (conceals himself behind the barrel, L.—SYDNEY descends and advances)

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: Now, sir, I am here.

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: Glad to find you are punctual.

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: It was not likely I should fail to our appointment, for you are my rival—you have intervened to thwart my happiness. To you does Lady Marian owe the misery she has had to endure, and that thought excites my rage—inspires me with a desire to kill you.

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: Do not be too impatient.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (aside) How will this terminate?

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: Say that you renounce the thoughts you have dared to cherish respecting Lady Marian! Swear that you will cease to persecute her!

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: I swear that Lady Marian shall become my wife.

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p:
Never, villain, never! (Music—he seizes JOE—they struggle—JANE and NOBBY eagerly watching them—JOE shakes himself free of
SYDNEY, and darting up places his back against the wall, C.)

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: Ah! coward, coward! (goes up towards JOE, and stops when a pace or two from him) But you shall not escape me.

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: There you are mistaken, my friend. (Music—JOE presses spring in the wall—a large trap flies open, C., beneath SYDNEY'S feet, and he falls and disappears—JOE walks hastily forward—JANE at same moment rises with an exclamation of terror)

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: (aside) I'll have his watch and chain for my young woman! (leaps down after SYDNEY—trap re—closes)

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (having seen nothing) That is well over!

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (without red wig—advancing and confronting him) Villain! Murderer!

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (confounded) Jane Rutherford!

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Yes; I have seen all, and though unable to save your victim, shall at least find a way to avenge him!

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: I have no fear of that, for, hark ye, Mrs. Rutherford, your daughter is here, in one of these cellars, and guarded by a man to whom my will is law, and should you utter one cry, or speak one word to denounce me—she dies!

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: No, no, impossible—it cannot be—Jessie in your power!

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: Yes; it was not Poynter, but I, myself, who hurried to your lodgings—exhausted by hunger and fatigue, your daughter was asleep, and I was prepared with means to render her slumber more profound.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (wringing her hands) Oh, heaven! Oh, heaven! Jessie here! But I will snatch her hence! Jessie! Jessie! (hurrying towards L.)

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (intercepting her) You do not stir.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: You shall not stay me, villain! you shall not stay me!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (without) Help! help!

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Ah! 'tis her voice. Jessie! Jessie! (dashes past JOE and meets MARIAN, who, running on L., flies into JANE's arms. —Music)

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.p: Mother! mother!

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (R., coldly) Well, Jane, do you believe me now?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (pressing her arms around MARIAN) Tremble not thus, darling; I will defend you—I will defend you!

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.p: Oh, how came I here, in this dreadful place? But you will save me, mother! you will save me!

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p:
Yes, yes. Do not fear. Come, darling, come. (Music. JANE is about to lead MARIAN towards back; JOE places himself before them and whistles; MEN hurry on, L.; JOE
points to JANE and MARIAN; all are advancing when JANE, producing a pistol, levels it towards them) Stand back, wretches! Stand back! (all retreat; JANE, dragging with her MARIAN, has reached and partly ascended steps, when she is driven back by the appearance of LORD CHESTERTON, POYNTER, and other POLICEMEN; seeing them, the THIEVES hurry off, L.)

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (aside, as LORD C. advances) So, he's come at last.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: I am here to demand my daughter, whom you, Jane Rutherford, have forcibly carried from me.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.p: No, my lord, no! Of my own free will I followed her, for she is my mother.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: You hear her—I am her mother! And you shall not tear her from me. No! you shall not. Dare you repeat, dare you say again, to her, that I am not her mother?

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: (aside to JANE) Shall I tell her that the mother whom she loves and honours has been made to groan beneath an infamous punishment?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (in a low voice) Oh, silence, silence! for mercy's sake! Anything, everything, rather than she should despise me!

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Well—(raising his voice) Confess, then, your imposture! confess that you have audaciously deceived her!

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (aside, weeping) Oh, heaven! again, again to lose her.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Speak quickly.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (with effort) Yes—yes—I confess it.

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (joyfully) Good!

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.p: What say you?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: That—that I have deceived you. No, I am not your mother! Pardon me, Lady Marian. Pardon! pardon! (sinks on her knees, with clasped hands, before MARIAN)

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.p: (greatly agitated) But wherefore have you deceived me? Wherefore that tenderness and devotion of which you have given me so many proofs? If not my mother, wherefore are you weeping now?

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: Am I to take Jane Rutherford into custody, my lord?

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: No, she has confessed, and I shall not prosecute her.

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: (aside) I shall wait for his lordship and say a word or two more to him. There is something I can't make out in all this, and I must hunt for proof. (goes off C. with POLICEMAN)

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Now, Marian, let us go.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.p: (who has been imploring LORD C., and now approaches JANE) You have been devoted to me, have succoured and protected me, whoever yon may be, I bless and shall ever love you.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (seizing MARIAN'S extended hand and covering it with kisses) Ah, they take not from me all!—her heart remains with me. (Music—MARIAN is led off, C., by LORD C., looking to the last on JANE. JOE follows them partly up steps, and when they have disappeared hastily returns to JANE, who is still kneeling)

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: You have done well to renounce your claims to Jessie, and when she is my wife, I shall allow you, now and then, to stand at a respectful distance and have a look at her.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (starting to her feet) Yours! Oh, I had forgotten that. No, no; so long as my heart shall throb, while a breath of life remains to me, I will assert my lawful claim to Jessie, and will not suffer her to know the shame and degradation of wedding with a wretch like thee!

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: Beware, Jane Rutherford, beware! (drawing knife) Swear you will be silent that you will not seek to oppose my marriage with your daughter. Swear it, or—

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Oh, mercy! let me live. To kill a mother that you marry with her daughter! oh, think how horrible that would be! Spare me! now that I have seen, have embraced my Jessie—I am afraid to die! Oh, have mercy on me! pity and spare me?

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: Swear, then, you will be silent, and you shall live.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: No, no. I would rather pray beside my Jessie's coffin—would see her dead—than wedded to a robber and an assassin!

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: You have reminded me that should I suffer you to live you might bring me to the scaffold.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (breaking from him and hurrying towards steps) Help! murder, help!

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (following and dragging her back) Curse you, die!

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (clutching his arm and grasping his throat) Demon! even dead I will oppose your infamous intentions—will return from the tomb to place myself before my daughter, and to guard her from you! (Music—he frees his arm, and stabs JANE, who falls, R. He is then hurrying off, L., when he is met by SYDNEY WESTON, who enters calm and pale—JOE, with a loud exclamation, recoils terrified, and the dagger falls from his hand. At the same moment LORD CHESTERTON and MARIAN appear on steps and partly descend, POYNTER and POLICEMEN standing behind them)

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: (L.) Coward! coward!

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (struggling to her feet, R.) Assassin—assassin!

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: (glaring at SYDNEY, C.) Not dead—not dead!

div.stage: Enter NOBBY, L.

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: No, my good friend; I took hold of his watch—chain, and fished him out! (OTHERS have advanced)

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: Ah, here's proof enough now—lock him up.

sp.speaker: Joe.
sp.p: I have played a bold game, and luck has gone against me, that's all. Don't be uneasy, my lord; it wouldn't do me any good to tell all I know, so I shall hold my tongue, and let them quietly finish me off. (is taken off by POLICEMEN, L.)

sp.speaker: Poynter.
sp.p: You are a good fellow at heart, Nobby, and I shall make something of you yet!

sp.speaker: Nobby.
sp.p: I'll never do another rascally trick as long as I live, and you shall soon have proof of that, uncle! (JANE has staggered and sunk on to stool near table—LORD C. and JESSIE support her)

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Oh, she is saved, she is saved! (placing her hand on her heart) Ah!

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.p: (alarmed) Oh, heaven!

div.stage: (Music, piano, till end—the same as at the first meeting of mother and daughter)

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: It is nothing—heaven in its mercy, will permit that I shall live.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.p: (at her feet) Yes, you will live—will remain with us—shall she not, my lord?

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Yes, Marian, yes.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.p: No, you shall never quit us, for I know, am certain, that you are my ——

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (putting her hand on MARIAN'S lips) Silence! for your own happiness, none must know—but sometimes—when you are alone, and very softly—you will pray for me, and then you will call me—

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.p: (in low voice) Mother, Mother!

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: (exstatically, her eyes raised towards heaven) Oh! heaven has then pardoned me! (she dies—tableau)

div.stage: Curtain.

div.note: MODERN COSTUMES, Suited to the character and position of the persons represented.
